prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High resolution 3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe 4 protostars at 3 mm at 0.093" resolution in order to characterize substructure on 1.5" toward these sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have configured the correlator for continuum only to maximize sensitivity to dust emission at 3 mm.

We have chosen the highest available resolution (0.093" at 3 mm) in order to closely match the beam of our VLA observation at 8 mm to more sensitively examine the substructures found at this resolution.
The largest angular scale of 1.5 arcseconds is sufficient to recover most emission from the full extent of the structures we are interested in probing. However, a more compact configuration is included as a separate science goal for comparison with the higher resolution imaging, such that we know what emission is being filtered out.

Our sensitivity is based on continuum only. The substructures detected at 8 mm wavelengths have surface brightnesses down to 30 microJy/beam at the 3 sigma limit. At 3 mm, with a comparable beam size, we aim to detect these extended dust structures with signal-to-noise ratio of 30, a factor of 10 better than the VLA data. Assuing a dust spectral index of 1, 30 microJy/beam at 8 mm corresponds to 628 microJy/beam at 3 mm and to observe this intensity with a signal-to-noise of 30, then we must integrate down to a sensitivity of 21 microJy/beam at 3 mm.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High resolution 1.3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image 4 protostars with 0.07" resolution to characterize substructure on $<$ 20 AU scales.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator is configured for maximum continuum bandwith for best sensitivity to dust emission.

We have chosen 0.06" in order to resolve the binary sources apparent toward three sources and to resolve the structure of dust emission surrounding these sources.
The largest angular scale of 0.65" will filter out some emission from the more extended sources, primarily IRAS 03292, but we will still be sensitive to the emission concentrated near the binary pair. A more compact configuration is included as a separate science goal for comparison with the higher resolution imaging, such that we know what emission is being filtered out.

Our sensitivity is based on continuum only. The substructures detected at 8 mm wavelengths have surface brightnesses down to 45 microJy/beam at the 3 sigma limit at 0.06" resolution. At 1.3 mm, with a comparable beam size, we aim to detect these extended dust structures with signal-to-noise ratio of 300. Assuing a dust spectral index of 1, 45 microJy/beam at 8 mm corresponds to 11200 microJy/beam at 1.3 mm and to observe this intensity with a signal-to-noise of 300, then we must integrate down to a sensitivity of 37 microJy/beam at 1.3 mm. This sensitivity will enable us to both detect the companions, but also examine the distribution of dust surrounding them.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lower resolution 3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image 4 protostars at 3 mm with 0.35" resolution (~4.0" maximum recoverable scale) to examine more extended structure not sampled by the long baseline observations. These observations are necessary to compare with the long baseline data such that we know what structure is resolved-out.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have configured the correlator for continuum only to maximize sensitivity to dust emission at 3 mm.

We have chosen 0.35" resolution in order to examine the underlying surface brightness distribution of dust emission at 3 mm toward the proposed sources. We will compare these images to the longer baseline observations such that we know what flux we are missing from those observations.
The largest angular scale of 4" is sufficient to fully recover the flux density from the structure observed with the VLA at 8mm.

Our sensitivity is based on continuum only. The substructures detected at 8 mm wavelengths have surface brightnesses down to 30 microJy/beam at the 3 sigma limit. At 3 mm, with a beam that is 0.35" we aim to achive the same surface brightness sensitivity. The ratio of beam areas (0.08/0.35)^2 = 0.05. Assuing a dust spectral index of 1, 30 microJy/beam at 8 mm corresponds to 628 microJy/beam (0.08"); accounting for the ratio of beam areas the surface brightness in a 0.35" beam is 12560 microJy/beam (12.56 mJy/beam) To observe this intensity with a signal-to-noise of 30x better than the VLA observations we only need a sensitivity of 420 microJy/beam. This will enable us to sample the underlying distribution of dust emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lower resolution 1.3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image 4 protostars at 1.3 mm with 0.3" resolution (~4.0" maximum recoverable scale) to examine more extended structure not sampled by the long baseline observations. These observations are necessary to compare with the long baseline data such that we know what structure is resolved-out.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator is configured for maximum continuum bandwith for best sensitivity to dust emission.

We have chosen 0.3" resolution in order to examine the underlying surface brightness distribution of dust emission at 1.3 mm toward the proposed sources. We will compare these images to the longer baseline observations such that we know what flux we are missing from those observations.
The largest angular scale of 4" is sufficient to fully recover the flux density from the structure observed with the VLA at 8mm.

Our sensitivity is based on continuum only. The substructures detected at 8 mm wavelengths have surface brightnesses down to 30 microJy/beam at the 3 sigma limit. At 1.3 mm, with a beam that is 0.35" we aim to achive the same surface brightness sensitivity. The ratio of beam areas (0.08/0.3)^2 = 0.07. Assuing a dust spectral index of 1, 30 microJy/beam at 8 mm corresponds to 11200 microJy/beam (0.08"); accounting for the ratio of beam areas the surface brightness in a 0.3" beam is 160000 microJy/beam (160 mJy/beam) To observe this intensity with a signal-to-noise of 300x better than the VLA observations we only need a sensitivity of 533 microJy/beam. This will enable us to sample the underlying distribution of dust emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose continuum observations at 3 mm and 1.3 mm at 0.093" and 0.06" resolution, respectively, toward four protostellar sources that have evidence of substructure detected in 8 mm VLA imaging at 0.065" (15 AU) resolution. Three of these sources have apparent companions separated by ~19 AU that are surrounded by dust emission. The fourth source does not appear to have a close companion, but has very high surface brightness dust emission from < 0.5" (115 AU) scales. However, the VLA data alone do not have sufficient signal to noise to characterize these structures. The proposed ALMA observations will have greater sensitivities to dust emission by factors of 10 and 100 at 3 mm and 1.3 mm. These sensitivities will enable us to further characterize the morphology of the substructures to determine if they result from gravitational instability. Thus, we may find direct evidence for disk fragmentation, potentially capturing the process of binary star formation and/or giant planet formation in the act toward these sources.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00316.S,'Are Close Binaries Formed Through Disk Fragmentation?', PI John Tobin 2015.1.00096.S, 'Characterizing the Kinematic Structure of VLA-Detected Protostellar Disk Candidates', PI John Tobin 2015.1.00354.S,'Detection of a Fragmenting Class 0 Disk', PI Mike Dunham 2015.1.01053.S,'Confirming the First Class 0 Circumbinary Disk', PI Dominique Segura-Cox
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2015.1.00031.S,'Are Close Binaries Formed Through Disk Fragmentation?', PI John Tobin
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
